text: "Just like students are given a couple of weeks of preparation before taking exams, doctors should also be given few days or weeks to prepare themselves before an operation or surgery, after all surgery is not as easy task" Is an example of....
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: You don't have to do this. My grandmother is in the hospital. I need my salary to support her medication. She's dying.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: I know five people from Kentucky. They are all racists. Therefore, Kentuckians are racist.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Pvt. Joe Bowers: What are these electrolytes? Do you even know? Secretary of State: They're... what they use to make Brawndo! Pvt. Joe Bowers: But why do they use them to make Brawndo? Secretary of Defense: [raises hand after a pause] Because Brawndo's got electrolytes.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: This is a fallacy of irrelevance that is based solely on someone's or something's history, origin, or source rather than its current meaning
label: Ad Hominem

text: Helga: You should not be eating that... it has been scientifically proven that eating fat burgers are no good for your health. Hugh: You eat fat burgers all the time so that can't be true.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Bill: I believe that abortion is morally wrong. Dave: Of course you would say that, you're a priest. Bill: What about the arguments I gave to support my position? Dave: Those don't count. Like I said, you're a priest, so you have to say that abortion is wrong. Further, you are just a lackey to the Pope, so I can't believe what you say.
label: Ad Hominem

text: If we use one more can of hairspray this month, the ozone layer will not exist, and we will not exist!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Argues that because something is popular, it must be right.
label: Ad Populum

text: We either have to cut taxes or leave a huge debt for our children.
label: False Dilemma

text: "Why would you elect a mayor whose wife has been treated for alcohol addiction?" This logical fallacy is called...
label: Ad Hominem

text: The best example of this fallacy is presented by the person who coined this term, Nassim Nicholas Taleb in his 2007 book, The Black Swan. There are two people
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: "I drank bottled water and now I am sick, so the water must have made me sick."
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Teenagers are too immature and self-absorbed to understand anything about global issues.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Ricky is watching television when he sees a commercial for foot cream. The commercial announcer says, "This is the best foot cream on the market because no other foot cream makers have been able to prove otherwise!"
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: "No one stops to process...No one appreciates the value" is an example of
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Everyone who is really into gaming already owns the latest video game. Don't be the only one left out! Which logical fallacy is being used in the passage?
label: Ad Populum

text: "A 2005 Gallup Poll found that an estimated 25% of Americans over the age of 18 believe in astrology - or that the position of the stars and planets can affect people's lives. This is roughly 75,000,000 people. Therefore, there must be some truth to astrology!"
label: Ad Populum

text: "Drivers in Richmond are terrible. Why does everyone in a big city drive like that?"
label: Ad Hominem

text: No people under the age of 66 are senior citizens. No senior citizens are children. Therefore, all people under the age of 66 are children.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: "Why worry about pandas going extinct, when we have the homeless in our country to worry about?"
label: Red Herring

text: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.
label: Equivocation

text: Everyone in our family has gone to the University of Tennessee, so you need to apply to UT.
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: Schools are like families; therefore teachers (like parents) should be allowed to discipline their students. Which logical fallacy is represented here?
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Recent auto accidents in your neighborhood have led you to propose to the city council that the speed limit along Main Street be reduced to calm the traffic flow. Opponents complain that reducing speed limits all over town is counterproductive and an unnecessary burden on drivers.
label: Straw Man

text: Whatever happens by chance should be punished, because whatever happens by chance is a departure from law and all departures from law should be punished. Identify the logical fallacy commited in this argument.
label: Equivocation

text: "The art teacher spoke in the trial as a witness in support of testing perfumes on animals, and he persuaded me."
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: P1. A sedentary lifestyle contributes to obesity. P2. People have become more sedentary in the last few decades. C. Therefore, the rise in obesity can be fixed by people getting more exercise.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Executions are moral because we must have a death penalty to discourage violent crime.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: Everyone knows that Japanese DVD players are the best. After all, the outsell American players two-to-one.
label: Ad Populum

text: Jimmy has a fever, sinus congestion, a cough, and can't come to school, so he probably has a test later today.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Lily says the sun is fully risen at 5:00am, but how would she know she sleeps in until noon. (love you lily all jokes all jokes)
label: Ad Hominem

text: Dr. Fauci says we need to wear masks, but Dr. Fauci is the oldest, meanest doctor around. I'm sure what he says isn't true at all.
label: Ad Hominem

text: You should drive on the right side of the road because that is what the law says, and the law is the law.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: "You shouldn't go to 'Vomito' I went once and the food was awful." is
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Buddy Burger has the greatest food in town. Buddy Burger was voted #1 by the local paper. Therefore, Phil, the owner of Buddy Burger, should run for president of the United States.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Robert Downey Jr. thinks everyone should vote. However, Robert Downey Jr. once went to prison for drug use. So, he's obviously wrong.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Let's talk about Glaucon. Where did you get the poison you used on him?
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: "The only solutions I can see to climate change is either mass extinction of humans, or passing this green bill."
label: False Dilemma

text: No kangaroos are MMA fighters. Some MMA fighters are not Mormons. Therefore, some Mormons are not kangaroos.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: People who have to have a cup of coffee every morning before they can function have no less a problem than alcoholics who have to have their alcohol each day to sustain them.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: The use of laptops and other devices to replace books in the classroom would eventually lead to the downfall of printing and publishing companies, causing many people to be laid off from their jobs. As such, schools should stick to using printed books as study materials.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Everybody know that staying out in the rain can make you sick. Which logical fallacy is represented here?
label: Ad Populum

text: "Historically, up until the late 16th century, most people believed that the Earth was the center of the universe. Today we understand this is not true,"
label: Ad Populum

text: James, the company you work for just filed for bankruptcy! How can I trust you with our money?
label: Faulty Generalization

text: All required university courses are boring.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: God exists. How do you know? Because it says so in the Bible.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: "Either we re-elect Mayor Ruiz, or we watch our city fall to pieces" is an example of
label: False Dilemma

text: Charlie: Fast food is filled with salt, fat, and added sugars. We need better regulation of the industry. Bob: That may be, but you're sure a hypocrite! I saw you devour a Triple-Baconator, super-sized fries, and 64 ounces of soda yesterday.
label: Ad Hominem

text: What is the appeal being used through this sad little girl?
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: "My opponent raises a really good point, but can we really trust him? He moved to this town three years ago and everyone knows his wife left him.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Sebastian saw that several of his friends had bought a new fidget spinner. He realized it must be a very cool gadget if they had one, and everyone else probably did, too.
label: Ad Populum

text: I know I missed assignments, but if you fail me, I will lose my financial aid and have to drop out.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: If you get in a car wreck, and the fault of the wreck is a teenage boy at ECR, believing all teenage boys at ECR are bad drivers is an example of:
label: Faulty Generalization

text: the phrase "Ninety percent of all people surveyed said that McDonalds is better than Burger King so it must be true." represents which fallacy?
label: Ad Populum

text: The Senator thinks we can solve all our ecological problems by driving a Prius.
label: Straw Man

text: Grizzly bears can't be dangerous! They're too cute.
label: Red Herring

text: My friend swears the mechanic at that shop overcharged her last week and after looking at her invoice it seems she's right. So don't take your business there, as you'll definitely get ripped off.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Asking students to sit in the same class for 2 hours is like asking them to wander the desert alone, with no water, for a week.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: My roommate said her philosophy class was difficult, and the one I'm in is difficult, too. All philosophy classes must be hard.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: It is an example of
label: False Dilemma

text: The Bible is filled with stories of God's magic.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: Pizza has ingredients from all the food groups. Therefore, pizza must be healthy.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: McDonald's Hamburgers: over 99 billion served.
label: Ad Populum

text: Mom, I know you're upset that I went over my cell limit this month. The important issue here, though, is that I got an A on my algebra exam.
label: Red Herring

text: An environmental group illegally blocked loggers and workers at a nuclear plant. Therefore, environmentalists are radicals who take the law into their own hands.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Look, you are going to have to make up your mind. Either you decide that you can afford this stereo, or you decide you are going to do without music for a while
label: False Dilemma

text: Either you love me or you hate me.
label: False Dilemma

text: Service Tech: Your car could use some new tires. Bart: You have a financial interest in selling me tires, why should I trust you? Service Tech: You brought your car to me to have it checked, sir. Bart: I brought my car to the shop where you work. Service Tech: So should we forget about the new tires for now? Bart: I never suggested that. Are you trying to use reverse psychology on me, so I will buy the tires?
label: Red Herring

text: Marcus wants to go to a small community college close to home because all of his friends are there.
label: Ad Populum

text: The thing about the new math teacher (who is an excellent teacher) is that he/she really stands out because he/she has good teaching skills.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: Smoking cigarettes is just like ingesting arsenic into your system; both have been shown to be causally related to death. If you wouldn't want to take a spoonful of arsenic, I would think that you wouldn't want to continue smoking.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: "The dinosaurs became extinct because they ate vegetables..." is an example of what?
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Of course that doctor advocates vaccinationhe probably owns stock in a pharmaceutical company.
label: Ad Hominem

text: SM 2: book being popular because it has been on the best-seller list for months
label: Ad Populum

text: "Yes, we have safety issues in our factory. But we work really hard to make a good product."
label: Red Herring

text: Guns are like hammers--they're both tools with metal parts that could be used to kill someone. And yet it would be ridiculous to restrict the purchase of hammers--so restrictions on purchasing guns are equally ridiculous.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: "I have a right to free speech so I can say what I want and you shouldn't try to stop me. "
label: Circular Reasoning

text: You didn't remember to take out the trash this morning. It will pile up and the neighbors will complain and the health inspectors will come and take away the kids.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: If you were a true American you would support the rights of people to choose whatever vehicle they want.
label: Ad Populum

text: David: Can you believe that the president said, "fat people are losers"? Sam: Where did you hear this? David: I read it in a headline on BrightBert News. Sam: He actually said, "People who say, 'fat people are losers' are not only cruel, but they are also wrong as well as being irrational."
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: If you eat a good diet, you will never have a heart attack.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: "With 80% of consumers choosing our product, isn't obvious that you should, too?" This logical fallacy is called...
label: Ad Populum

text: When your mom gets your phone bill and you have gone over the data limit, you begin to distract her by talking about how well you did on a test today knowing she has offered to extend your data limit if you make good grades. This is an example of which logical fallacy?
label: Red Herring

text: Some students failed a test last week and they all had cell phones. Having cell phones, therefore, made them fail.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: All professional athletes use Apple watches to track their training, so our team needs to purchase Apple watches for everyone.
label: Ad Populum

text: "The university committee for student discipline investigated all engineering tests for the past five years, and they found no evidence of cheating. We thus declare that no cheating has taken place during those five years."
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: People who are psychotic act in a bizarre manner. This person acts in a bizarre manner. Therefore: This person is psychotic.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Reporter: It's been two years since your policies were implemented, and so far they have failed to reduce unemployment rates. Politician: I have been working hard ever since I came into office, and I'm happy to say that I met with many business leaders throughout the country, who all say that they are glad to see that our hard work is paying off.
label: Red Herring

text: Representative Gutierrez of Illinois, arguing in Congress on July 11, 1996, replying to Republicans arguing in favor of the "Defense of Marriage Act", a bill stipulating that 'marriage' be defined as being between a man and a woman only, excluding homosexual marriages: "I now realize that my friends on the other side of the aisle aren't the least bit serious when they talk about how important it is for the federal government not to interfere in the lives of our people. I understand that they are just kidding - just teasing us - when they stress the importance of taking power out of Washington and giving it to local officials. And now I know that their biggest joke of all is that old line about family values - all that talk about encouraging people to care about and be committed to each other."
label: Ad Hominem

text: Well, every one else jumped off the roof, why can't I?
label: Ad Populum

text: Trump cites (biased) poll results showing that people think he's a strong leader to prove a point that he is a strong leader. ABC News/Washington Post Poll (wrong big on election) said almost all stand by their vote on me & 53% said strong leader.
label: Ad Populum

text: This crash will likely damage the reputation of Malaysia Airlines, which will hurt the tourism industry of Malaysia and ruin their economy.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Green Peace's strategies aren't effective because they are all dirty, lazy hippies.
label: Ad Hominem

text: In both of the murder mysteries I have read, the District Attorney was the culprit. All mystery writers like to make lawyers out to be villains.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Mayor Jones' anti-DUI campaign should not be taken seriously. After all, the mayor himself was cited for driving under the influence in college
label: Ad Hominem

text: A man who has cheated on his spouse is confronted by a friend who tells him that it is wrong. The man begins to talk about right versus wrong and who decides.
label: Red Herring

text: Bill and Jill are arguing about cleaning out their closets: Jill: "We should clean out the closets. They are getting a bit messy." Bill: "Why, we just went through those closets last year. Do we have to clean them out everyday?" Jill: "I never said anything about cleaning them out every day. You just want too keep all your junk forever, which is just ridiculous."
label: Straw Man

text: Jeff's mom is concerned when she finds out that he skipped class one day. She tells him that she is concerned that since he skipped one class, he will start skipping more frequently. Then he will drop out altogether, never graduate or get into college, and end up unemployed and living at home for the rest of his life. What type of fallacy has Jeff's mom committed?
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Red had come up six times in a row on the roulette wheel, so Greg knew that it was close to certain that black would be next up. Suffering an economic form of natural selection with this thinking, he soon lost all of his savings.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: "Once you leave the house, you cannot go back. You will not receive any financial support so you need to stop going to school. Your credit card will be cut so you need to work. You will live on your own."
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Person 1: If you are a Marvel fan then you love Avengers: Endgame. Person 2: I am a Marvel fan and I did not love Avengers: Endgame. Person 1: Well you aren't a TRUE Marvel fan.
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: This has to work so it will work.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: P1. Smoking has been empirically proven to cause lung cancer. C. Therefore, if we eradicate smoking, we will eradicate lung cancer.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: "Either we have the full football season or we scrap it altogether and have zero football"
label: False Dilemma

text: Robot 2 (Blue) has been refuting all of Robot 1's (Orange) arguments. Robot 1 launches the above counterargument. What is this fallacy?
label: Straw Man

text: Sure, that charity group is under investigation for misusing funds, but everyone deserves a healthy meal.
label: Red Herring

text: A shopkeeper suspects you of stealing and asks you to empty your pockets. The first thing you take out is an empty gum wrapper and they immediately shout, I knew it!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: The United States is the wealthiest nation in the world. So every American is wealthy.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Jack threw up because he ate Hot Cheetos.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Did John ever give up his bad habits?
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: I passed my math test after going out to the movies the night before. I should go to the movies the night before every math test!
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: "It's important for you to take this psychology course. Sign up today. Don't wait."
label: Red Herring

text: "My opponent suggests that lowering taxes will be a good idea, this is coming from a woman to eats a pint of Ben and Jerry's each night!"
label: Ad Hominem

text: Before women got the vote, there were no nuclear weapons
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: a connection between two ideas that doesn't always mean that one causes the other (correlation vs. causation) una conexin entre dos ideas que no siempre significa que una causa la otra (correlacin vs. causacin)
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: My best friend says you're a liar, so I'm not going to talk to you.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Maria drives a car. She must be wealthy.
label: Ad Hominem

text: 1. All the schools in the area had to kept closed for most part of the week. 2. Many parents have withdrawn their children from the local schools.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: What type of persuasive writing is used to influence readers' feelings (pathos)?
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: We should prohibit all cadets from assisting on emergency services missions. Some cadets are so immature they won't ever stop goofing around.
label: Straw Man

text: Teacher: Why don't you have your homework today? Student: Well, I did my homework. I was actually really interested in all that info about the quadratic formula. Would you like to hear the song that I wrote to memorize it?
label: Red Herring

text: Pastor Pete: People are turning to God everywhere! 9 out of 10 people I interviewed said that they had a personal relationship with Jesus Christ. Fred: Where did you find these people you interviewed? Pastor Pete: In my church.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: If you are a true American, you will ask your congressman to vote against NAFTA.
label: Ad Populum

text: "Everyone is doing it, you should be too!" is an example of which fallacy?
label: Ad Populum

text: A is part of B. A has property X. Therefore, B has property X.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Mabel wants to get rid of the student newspaper. Next she will probably want to ban free speech! She won't want us to speak at all! She will make it a law that you cannot speak in public.
label: Straw Man

text: A Congressman calls a Whitehouse Spokesperson a "giant idiot"
label: Ad Hominem

text: "You are not a credible resource person. You haven't finished college."
label: Ad Hominem

text: A commercial shows a group of friends all hanging out wearing clothes from a popular clothing company. This is an example of
label: Ad Populum

text: I cannot get a job because the public education system failed me; I have to steal to survive. It is society's fault, not mine.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: President Jones raised taxes, and then the rate of violent crime went up. Jones is responsible for the rise in crime."
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: How do I know the adult film industry is the third largest industry in the United States? Derek Shlongmiester, the adult film star of over 50 years, said it was. That's how I know.
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: Alissa has class with a football player who is a class clown. He disrupts the class and is failing. Alissa decides all football players are not serious students.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Fast food is bad for you because is junk.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: Elba: I can't believe the art critic said my artwork is awful! Rowena: He must have meant it in the old sense of the word -- that your artwork inspired awe! Elba: Yes! That makes sense now!
label: Equivocation

text: "We're going to protest and not get in trouble because Mr. Iglesias said it's okay."
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: If I don't take this AP class, then I won't do well on the exam. If I don't do well on the AP exam, then I can't get into a good college. If I can't get into a good college, then I'll never get a good job. If I can't get a good job, then I'm going to have to live in my parents' basement forever. Guess I'll sign up for the AP class.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Every time I wear this necklace, I pass my exams. Therefore, wearing this necklace causes me to pass my exams.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Everyone is getting tattoos in college, so you might as well do it too.
label: Ad Populum

text: There is no need for additional taxes for education. Every year we throw more money into education, and all they do is hire more management and build more buildings. None of the money actually reaches the classroom or is really used for education.
label: Red Herring

text: Mrs. Peters is nominated for teacher of the year, which is voted on by her fellow faculty members. A colleague says that she would never vote for her because she is too young.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Don't believe what Kim says about global warming. Kim dropped out of college!
label: Ad Hominem

text: You're complaining because you have to walk to school? I used to have to give my parents my entire paycheck.
label: Red Herring

text: This coin has landed heads-up nine times in a row. So it will probably land tails-up next time it is tossed.
label: Ad Populum

text: Son: I am so excited! I got an A on my physics exam! Dad: Why not an A+? This means that you answered something incorrectly. That is not acceptable!
label: Red Herring

text: "The Cardinals are the best football team because they're better than all the other teams. They're better than all the other teams because they're the best."
label: Circular Reasoning

text: How can you tell me I should exercise to lose weight? All you do is sit behind a desk all day. I've never seen you do a lick of exercise.
label: Ad Hominem

text: There are two kinds of people in this world: those who like penguins, and those who are terrible monsters.
label: False Dilemma

text: "Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste. Therefore, it must be great."
label: Faulty Generalization

text: A mother says that she does not trust her pediatrician because he has never been a mother.
label: Ad Hominem

text: She has always associated with shady people, so she must not be trustworthy.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Our garage sale made lots of money before Joan showed up. Obviously, she scared off all the customers.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Speaker 1: No fault divorce is really harmful to the family and the larger society. Speaker 2: Well, you must not really think that since you're divorced yourself.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Mark: Do you believe in virgin births? Sue: You mean that babies are born virgins? Mark: I mean birth without fertilization. Sue: No. Mark: How could you not believe in virgin births? Roughly two billion people believe in them, don't you think you should reconsider your position?
label: Ad Populum

text: After Will said that we should put more money into health and education, Warren responded by saying that he was surprised that Will hates our country so much that he wants to leave it defenceless by cutting military spending.
label: Straw Man

text: I didn't want to the only one not listening to music while I completed my Achieve article, so I listened to music too.
label: Ad Populum

text: If we take away farmers' ability to grow genetically engineered crops, if we eliminate that option, people will go hungry, in fact, people will starve. Unlike my opponent, I choose to use the technology available to us and save lives.
label: Straw Man

text: I thought you were a good person, but you were not at church today.
label: False Dilemma

text: "We both like music, so we should get married."
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy Smiley toothpaste brand. Therefore, it must be great.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: What drugs were you on?
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: Guns are like hammersthey're both tools with metal parts that could be used to kill someone. And yet it would be ridiculous to restrict the purchase of hammersso restrictions on purchasing guns are equally ridiculous.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: A car makes less pollution than a bus. Therefore, cars are less of a pollution problem than buses
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Sam is riding her bike in her home town in Maine, minding her own business. A station wagon comes up behind her and the driver starts beeping his horn and then tries to force her off the road. As he goes by, the driver yells "get on the sidewalk where you belong!" Sam sees that the car has Ohio plates and concludes that all Ohio drivers are jerks.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: I'm raising funds to help cure XYZ disease. If you don't donate, then you're part of the problem.
label: False Dilemma

text: If we let the government implant tracking devices in criminals, it's not going to stop there! They're going to want to track us at work, our school children, and then eventually everyone!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Jay: Dude, where are my car keys? Silent Bob: (says nothing) Jay: I KNEW you took them!
label: Red Herring

text: Starbucks is the best because it's expensive.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: I saw two women get in a car accident. Therefore, all women are bad drivers
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Matthew: Everyone believes that teachers get paid enough for the job they do. Therefore, it must be true.
label: Ad Populum

text: If your neighbor robs a bank, should you go to jail? is an example of.....
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: Jon: "Go easy on the scotch; you've had three shots already now." Jeff: "Oh sure, I'll put down my scotch when you put down that tequila. Lay off, man."
label: Red Herring

text: Broccoli has significantly less fat than the leading candy bar! Plus, it's nowhere near as hot as Hot Cheetos!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Although we have proven that the moon is not made of spare ribs, we have not proven that its core cannot be filled with them; therefore, the moon's core is filled with spare ribs. X is true because you cannot prove that X is false. X is false because you cannot prove that X is true.
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: Violent video games cause teens to be violent, because violent teens play violent video games.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: A 2005 Gallup Poll found that an estimated 25% of Americans over the age of 18 believe in astrologyor that the position of the stars and planets can affect people's lives. That is roughly 75,000,000 people. Therefore, there must be some truth to astrology!
label: Ad Populum

text: I saw Ashton Kutcher in a commercial for male skin care. He's looking good for his age, so I'm willing to try the product. He must know what he's talking about.
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: Trying the latest social media challenge is a good example of what logical fallacy?
label: Ad Populum

text: Murder is morally wrong. Therefore, abortion is morally wrong.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: The party was going great! Then Gerald showed up and little by little people started collecting their coats and heading home. Gerald ruined the party.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: The Supreme Court right now is deciding whether it is right to execute insane people who have committed murder. I think it is all right to execute insane people. If we ban executions of insane people, then everybody on death row will suddenly decide they are insane and purposely fail sanity tests. It would result in chaos.
label: Red Herring

text: "That new home looks great! Let's buy it!"
label: Faulty Generalization

text: After I listened to the first song of my favorite musician's new vinyl record, I knew I'd hate the entire record, so I converted it into a Frisbee.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: John: Members of the UbaTuba White Men's Club are upstanding citizens of the community. Marvin: Then why are there so many of these members in jail? John: They were never true UbaTuba White Men's Club members. Marvin: What's a true UbaTuba White Men's Club member? John: Those who don't go to jail.
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: Tries to persuade the reader to do, think or buy something because it is popular or because "everyone" is doing it.
label: Ad Populum

text: Why worry about taking attendance when there are so many starving children in the world?
label: Red Herring

text: Purchase our product or no one is going to think you're attractive.
label: False Dilemma

text: Senator Lewis says we should not fund the missile attack program. I disagree. I don't understand why he wants to leave us defenseless like that.
label: Straw Man

text: This is an emotional appeal that speaks the concept that many people agree or disagree, so you should, too
label: Ad Populum

text: Everyone being referred to as comrade.
label: Ad Populum

text: Slavery is accepted by just about everyone in our society, so it's ethical to keep slaves.
label: Ad Populum

text: You tell me it's unpatriotic to cheat on federal income tax reports. Well, you should know. You've never once listed your huge bonuses.
label: Red Herring

text: I shop at Natural Happy Sunshine Store (NHSS), which is much better than your grocery store because at NHSS everything is natural including the 38-year-old store manager's long gray hair and saggy breasts.
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: I took a vitamin this morning and now I'm sick, so the vitamin must have made me ill.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Get Verizon--1 billion people can't be wrong.
label: Ad Populum

text: "If I raise you, I must raise everyone, and then the company goes bankrupt."
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Atheists are morally bankrupt.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Last year I wanted to quit school because my friends treated me like an outcast and talked about me to my friends. I felt betrayed and sad all of the time but now I think I have a place at my new middle school.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: In order to really look at the problem of global warming, we must first consider how the homeless suffer when it is cold.
label: Red Herring

text: Why should we worry about the negative depiction of women in music videos when thousands of women are dying of AIDS each year?
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Donald Trump mocked Romney for walking like a penguin. He also repeatedly called Jeb Bush low-energy.
label: Ad Hominem

text: French people are great at kissing. Julie is French. Get me a date!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: First we handed out I-pads, now we use Quizizz, next we'll have robot subs!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: There was a thunderstorm with rain therefore I did not finish my homework.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: The sinister fisherman's suspicious smile frightened the innocent children
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: I guess I should buy my 12-year-old daughter an iPhone. Everyone at her new school has one and I want her to fit in with the other kids.
label: Ad Populum

text: "Everyone else believes it, so it must be true."
label: Ad Populum

text: Charlie: Fast food is filled with salt, fat, and added sugars. We need better regulation of the industry. Bob: That may be, but you're such a hypocrite! I saw you devour a Triple-Baconator, super-sized fries, and 64 ounces of soda yesterday.
label: Ad Hominem

text: , motive, or other attribute of the person making the argument.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Speaker 1: I'll never talk. Speaker 2: We have ways of making you talk.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: Last week, the Cowboys played the Texans in Houston. Mrs. Gibson was excited to go to the game because she is a huge Cowboys fan. Because everyone in Houston cheers for the Texans, Mrs. Gibson decided to cheer for the Texans too.
label: Ad Populum

text: Everyone is doing it. You should too.
label: Ad Populum

text: Join the crowd and don't get left behind!
label: Ad Populum

text: "There I was in the midst of thousands, and yet a perfect stranger; without home and without friends, in the midst of thousands of my own brethrenchildren of a common Father, and yet I dared not to unfold to any one of them my sad condition." Check each literary term found in this quote:
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: We cannot unlock our child from the closet because if we do, she will want to roam the house. If we let her roam the house, she will want to roam the neighborhood. If she roams the neighborhood, she will get picked up by a stranger in a van, who will sell her in a sex slavery ring in some other country. Therefore, we should keep her locked up in the closet.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Even though it's only the first day, I can tell this is going to be a boring course.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Eugene is silly in class. Harry is his friend, so Harry must be silly, too.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: "How would you know anything about technology? You're too old!"
label: Ad Hominem

text: "Everybody is late coming back from lunch, so it shouldn't matter if I'm late."
label: Ad Populum

text: Lots of people bought this album, so it must be good.
label: Ad Populum

text: My child was diagnosed with autism after receiving vaccinations. That is proof that vaccines are to blame.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: My parents are democrats, and they are good people. Therefore, all democrats must be good people.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: "You can't prove that mermaids actually don't exist and therefore it's reasonable to say that they do" IS an example of this fallacy.
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: All Greek gods are mythical. All modern day gods are real. Therefore, all Greek gods are real.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: The senator voted for the tax increase. It's not hard to understand why when you consider that he is a millionaire and has never had to worry about money.
label: Ad Hominem

text: Susie bought a flip-phone, so all of her friends bought flip-phones.
label: Ad Populum

text: Now that the Chiefs are going to the Super Bowl, everybody is suddenly a fan.
label: Ad Populum

text: Sure, we haven't given raises to our employees in more than ten years. However, we do pride ourselves on providing customer service in over seven different languages.
label: Red Herring

text: Nicholas - "An apple is a vegetable." Alexis - "Don't listen to Nicholas; he is failing AP Language"
label: Ad Hominem

text: Laura is the class president. She believes that the class should sponsor a dance as a fundraiser. Then she learns that a group of girls that she doesn't like also support the idea of a dance as a fundraiser. So, Laura changes her mind and decides that the class should plan a race instead.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: I can't stop eating these chocolates. I really love chocolate, or I seriously lack willpower. I know I really love chocolate; therefore, I cannot lack willpower.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Did you really vote for Donald as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?
label: Faulty Generalization

text: All of my friends are coming to my birthday party. If Micah doesn't, she might as well tell me that she doesn't like me.
label: False Dilemma

text: No donkeys are fish. Some asses are donkeys. Therefore, some asses are fish.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: I've never had the flu because I take my vitamins everyday.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: We either ban hairspray or the world will end.
label: False Dilemma

text: A speaker chooses a deliberately poor or oversimplified example in order to ridicule and refute an idea
label: Straw Man

text: Everyone I know is making fruit smoothies for quick, portable meals, so smoothies must be really good for you.
label: Ad Populum

text: If we allow a housing development to be built on Sunny Lake, a resort will come next, and soon we won't have any wilderness left!
label: Faulty Generalization

text: A: Many stores are telling their employees to say Happy Holidays instead of Merry Christmas. B: This is crazy! Why are they trying to get rid of Christmas?!
label: Straw Man

text: The government is convinced that it was a bomb that brought down the aircraft. Our countrymen believe it was a bomb, said the president. A survey done a few days after the crash indicates that almost seventy percent of the people believe it was a terrorist's bomb.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Trying to finish a marathon is impossible, I know because I tried it once.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Teacher: You are receiving a zero because you didn't do your homework. Students: Are you serious? You gave me a zero because you hate me????
label: Straw Man

text: That German, Fred, stole my wallet. All Germans are thieves.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: person 1 : "We should argue with logic facts" person 2: "You should grow a brain before you open your mouth"
label: Ad Hominem

text: We should present Cadet Curry with our squadron's cadet of the year award. He's the most active and highest-performing cadet we have. REPLY: But Cadet Arnold has been in CAP longer.
label: Red Herring

text: The more things change, the more they remain the same.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Utah passed a strict gun-control law, and crime there decreased. Therefore, gun-control laws decrease crime.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: Bill: I think capital punishment is wrong. Adam: No it isn't. If it was wrong, it wouldn't be legal. Of which fallacy is this an example? http://www.funtrivia.com
label: Circular Reasoning

text: Premise: All black bears are omnivores. Premise: All raccoons are omnivores. Conclusion: All raccoons are black bears.
label: Fallacy of Converse (Affirming the Consequent)

text: Running in the halls at school is against the rules. Therefore, the indoor track team should be written up.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: I thought you were a good person, but you weren't at church today.
label: False Dilemma

text: I saw a student texting in my class yesterday; all my students must be texting, so cell phones should be banned.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: The temperature has dropped this morning, and I also have a headache. Therefore, the cold weather must be causing my headache.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: A commercial about abandoned animals needing a shelter of a forever home. They ask for a small donation to help these struggling animals.
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: "You can be a good politician and play dirty or you can drop out."
label: False Dilemma

text: "I don't know how Professor Resnick can be such a hard grader. He's always late for class. "
label: Ad Hominem

text: The purpose of the Cadet Program is to prepare youth for Air Force Basic Military Training. REPLY: This is true because I heard it from the Wing Commander.
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: 4 out of 5 dentists recommend this toothpaste! (only 5 were asked. Out of 1000 asked, only 20% recommend it)
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: It is said that we have a good understanding of our universe. Therefore, we know exactly how it began and when.
label: Equivocation

text: We can't freeze the academic year because then students won't graduate on time. Next thing you know most people will be unemployed and will resort to crime. The crime rate will skyrocket and society will collapse. No podemos congelar el ao acadmico porque entonces los estudiantes no se graduarn a tiempo. Lo siguiente que sabes es que la mayora de la gente estar desempleada y recurrir al crimen. La tasa de criminalidad se disparar y la sociedad colapsar.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: If we allow our 14 year-old to have her first date tonight, what's next? A wedding, kids?
label: Faulty Generalization

text: If we put limits on the right to bear arms, soon all of our Constitutionally-given rights will be taken away.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: A is true because A is true.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: Have you stopped beating your wife?
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: No one in your family surfs? But I thought you said you lived in California before this.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Holly said that vaccinations caused autism in children, but her scientifically well-read friend Caleb said that this claim had been debunked and proven false. Their friend Alice offered a compromise that vaccinations must cause some autism, just not all autism.
label: Red Herring

text: Teacher: If I let you go to the bathroom pretty soon everybody will want to go to the bathroom. This is an example of
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Your friend says, "You can't prove that space aliens don't exist, so they must be real". This is an example of which logical fallacy?
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: This is when you characterize someone with one extreme trait in order to more effectively tear them down.
label: Straw Man

text: 40 million people can't be wrong! Buy the new iPhone XIV today!
label: Ad Populum

text: Smoking pot is against the law because it's wrong; I know it's wrong because it is against the law.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: I believe that when we die, we are all given new, young, perfect bodies, and we spend eternity with those whom we love. I can't imagine the point of life if it all just ends when we die!
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: Student: You didn't teach us this; we never learned this. Teacher: So, you're either lazy or unwilling to learn is that right?
label: False Dilemma

text: Which fallacy is the following example? "By rejecting God, you are rejecting goodness, kindness, and love itself."
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: Ginger: Your dog just ran into our house and ransacked our kitchen! Mary: He would never do that, look at how adorable he is with those puppy eyes!
label: Appeal to Emotion

text: SM 6: North invading South during Civil War
label: Straw Man

text: This new test seemed so promising, but the 3 studies that supported its validity turned out to have critical methodological flaws, so the test is probably not valid.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: earthquakes in the Andes were correlated with the closest approaches of the planet Uranus. Therefore, Uranus must have caused them.
label: False Causality (Post Hoc Fallacy)

text: attaching an argument to a person of false or appeared authority in order to give credence to their argument
label: Attack Credibility (Doubt)

text: Form: Idea X is popular. Therefore, X is correct.
label: Ad Populum

text: It says in the Bible that God exists. Since the Bible is God's word, and God never speaks falsely, then everything in the Bible must be true. So, God must exist.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: I shouldn't have to pay for my parking ticket. There are far more dangerous offenses people commit. They should have to pay.
label: Red Herring

text: My sister loves shopping, so all girls must love to shop too.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Speaker 1: I'm against the war. Speaker 2: You must hate our troops.
label: False Dilemma

text: Vote for me or live through four more years of higher taxes.
label: False Dilemma

text: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.
label: Equivocation

text: Two members of my team have become more engaged employees after taking public speaking classes. That proves we should have mandatory public speaking classes for the whole company to improve employee engagement.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: Justin claimed that passing federal laws to control the amount of violence in music is the first step in a process that will eventually result in absolute government control of the media and total censorship over all forms of artistic expression.
label: Faulty Generalization

text: I'm raising money to help cure XYZ disease. If you do not donate, you are part of the problem.
label: False Dilemma

text: SM 7: No global warming happening
label: Ad Populum

text: Paranormal activity is real because I have experienced what can only be described as paranormal activity.
label: Circular Reasoning

text: "Once a year, a miracle causes this large rock to float about ten centimeters off the ground since supernatural powers want us to remember the martyrs who died in that spot."
label: Circular Reasoning

text: "Do not listen to Luisa, she will only tell you lies about the recent activities given in our EAPP class."
label: Ad Hominem

text: Jojo: All New Yorkers are tough Charli: I get shoved in a locker every day and cry when I see bunnies Jojo: Well, REAL New Yorkers are tough Charli: What does toughness have to do with Geography? Jojo: Todos los neoyorquinos son duros Charli: Me empujan en un casillero todos los das y lloro cuando veo conejitos. Jojo: Bueno, los verdaderos neoyorquinos son duros. Charli: Qu tiene que ver la dureza con la geografa?
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: The Windmill debate- Snowball promises that the Windmill will mean less work and better living conditions. Napoleon says that it's just unnecessary and will be more work.
label: Intentional (Intentionally wrong argument)

text: Charlie: Fast food is filled with salt, fat, and added sugars. We need better regulation of the industry. Bob: That my be, but you're such a hypocrite! I saw you devour a Triple-Baconator, super-sized fries, and 64oz of soda yesterday!
label: Ad Hominem

text: Boris is not qualified to make suggestions about our penal system. As an ex-convict, he would always take the criminals' side.
label: Ad Hominem

text: President Bush argues that we should open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling. But Bush just wants to reward his rich cronies in the oil industry, so we can't take his arguments seriously.
label: Ad Hominem
